metadata.title: OpenShift Container Platform 4 Component Definition for ISA/IEC 62443-4-2 SL-4

components.title: Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform
components.description: A comprehensive enterprise Kubernetes platform for building and running cloud-native applications, configured to meet ISA/IEC 62443-4-2 SL-4.

control-implementations.description: Implementation of ISA/IEC 62443-4-2 controls for an SL-4 baseline.

implemented-requirements.description:
**Method:** Procedural (Identity Provider Configuration)

OpenShift delegates user authentication to an external OIDC-compliant Identity Provider (IdP). The customer is responsible for configuring the IdP to enforce strong authentication policies, including unique user identification. This satisfies the core requirement for identifying and authenticating human users on all interfaces.

**Method:** Procedural (Identity Provider Configuration)

Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enforced by the external IdP. The customer must configure their IdP to require a cryptographic MFA token (e.g., FIDO2 security key, smart card) for all users accessing the OpenShift cluster.

**Method:** Built-in

OpenShift provides unique identities for all software processes and internal components using Kubernetes ServiceAccounts. Each pod is associated with a ServiceAccount, which is used to authenticate to the Kubernetes API server, ensuring all intra-cluster actions are auditable and subject to RBAC.

**Method:** Automated (Manifest) & Procedural (KMS Configuration)

OpenShift can protect authenticators and other secrets at rest (e.g., etcd data) by integrating with an external Key Management Service (KMS) that is backed by a Hardware Security Module (HSM). The customer is responsible for provisioning the KMS/HSM and configuring the integration via the APIServer custom resource.

**Method:** Built-in

OpenShift includes a robust internal Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) that automatically issues, manages, and rotates x.509 certificates for all core cluster components. This ensures all control plane communication is mutually authenticated and encrypted with TLS.

**Method:** Procedural (Identity Provider Configuration)

The external IdP is responsible for detecting and mitigating brute-force attacks by enforcing policies for unsuccessful login attempts, including account lockout.

**Method:** Automated (Manifest)

A system use notification banner can be displayed on the web console login page by configuring the `Console` custom resource. This is typically managed via a GitOps workflow.

**Method:** Procedural (GitOps Workflow)

All user and process permissions are governed by Kubernetes Role-Based Access Control (RBAC). The customer is responsible for defining all `Roles`, `ClusterRoles`, and their `Bindings` as code in a Git repository. This enforces the principle of least privilege.

**Method:** Procedural (GitOps Workflow)

A dual-approval mechanism is implemented by enforcing a mandatory peer review process (e.g., via GitHub pull requests) for any change to the RBAC manifests stored in the GitOps repository.

**Method:** Automated (Manifest)

Session lock is implemented via configurable timeouts for the OAuth access tokens used by the web console and CLI. This is configured in the `OAuth` custom resource.

**Method:** Built-in & Procedural (SIEM Integration)

OpenShift generates detailed, structured audit logs for every API server request, capturing all necessary event details. The customer is responsible for forwarding these logs to a centralized SIEM for long-term storage, correlation, and analysis by configuring the `ClusterLogForwarder` custom resource.

**Method:** Automated (Manifest)

Time source integrity is ensured by configuring all cluster nodes to synchronize with multiple, trusted internal NTP servers. This is configured via a `MachineConfig` object.

**Method:** Automated (Manifest)

Communication integrity for the control plane is enforced by setting a `Modern` TLS security profile on the `APIServer` custom resource, which restricts the API server to using only strong, modern cryptographic ciphers and protocols.

**Method:** Built-in (SELinux) & Automated (Operator)

OpenShift provides multiple layers of protection against malicious code. RHCOS, the immutable host OS, runs with SELinux in enforcing mode by default. Additionally, the File Integrity Operator (FIO) can be deployed to monitor for and report on unauthorized changes to critical files on each node.

**Method:** Automated (Manifest)

The execution of unauthorized 'mobile code' (container images) is prevented by configuring an `ImageContentSourcePolicy` to ensure that images can only be pulled from a trusted, internally managed container registry.

**Method:** Automated (Operator)

The OpenShift Compliance Operator provides automated, continuous verification of the cluster's security configuration. It scans the cluster against a defined profile (e.g., CIS Benchmark) and reports on any configuration drift.

**Method:** Procedural (Storage Configuration)

Confidentiality for persistent application data is the responsibility of the underlying storage system. The customer must use a `StorageClass` that is configured to provide encryption-at-rest for all persistent volumes.

**Method:** Built-in (FIPS Mode)

OpenShift can be installed in a FIPS 140-2/3 validated mode, which ensures that all cryptographic modules used by the platform meet stringent federal standards. This is a configuration choice made at installation time.

**Method:** Automated (Manifest)

Network segmentation and restricted data flow within the cluster are achieved through Kubernetes `NetworkPolicy` objects. A 'default-deny' policy should be applied to critical namespaces to block all ingress traffic by default, with additional policies to explicitly allow required communication paths.

**Method:** Built-in & Procedural

OpenShift provides DoS protection through built-in API server rate limiting. The customer is responsible for creating `ResourceQuota` and `LimitRange` objects for all namespaces to prevent resource exhaustion from applications.

**Method:** Automated (Manifest)

Resource availability for critical applications is ensured by setting guaranteed CPU and memory resources (where requests equal limits) in the application's `Deployment` or `StatefulSet` manifest.

**Method:** Automated (Operator) & Procedural

Backup and recovery are managed by the OpenShift API for Data Protection (OADP) operator. The customer is responsible for installing and configuring this operator to perform regular backups of cluster resources and persistent data to a secure, off-site location.

**Method:** Procedural

The principle of least functionality is applied by disabling any unnecessary cluster operators or capabilities during the initial cluster installation.

**Method:** Built-in

An inventory of all core cluster components and their versions is maintained by the Cluster Version Operator (CVO) and can be retrieved using the `oc get clusterversion` command.

**Method:** Infrastructure

This control is not satisfied by the OpenShift software. The customer is responsible for ensuring the physical security of the data center, including locked racks and surveillance, and for using server hardware with chassis intrusion detection.

**Method:** Infrastructure

This control is satisfied by the underlying server hardware and the RHCOS operating system. The customer must enable UEFI Secure Boot in the server BIOS.

**Method:** Infrastructure

This control is not satisfied by the OpenShift software. The customer is responsible for ensuring the data center facility is equipped with Uninterruptible Power Supplies (UPS) and backup generators.
